image.altText: A woman wearing a visor and holding a tennis racket stands in a tennis court next to a loop fence.

props.synopsis: The impending departure of Rio Tinto raises concerns about the future of sporting clubs in Nhulunbuy. But there are hopes increased investment in regional sports can help sustain the community's active lifestyle.

title.children: Sporting clubs fear the worst as mining giant withdraws from Nhulunbuy

image.altText: Stationary construction vehicles and various pieces of equipment dotted around a large patch of red dirt by the water's edge.

props.synopsis: The NT government will gain no direct revenue from the ship lift project, despite spending $820 million on its construction.

title.children: Darwin ship lift should proceed despite $720m cost increase, report finds

image.altText: A healthcare worker giving a Band-Aid to a young Indigenous child.

props.synopsis: Imagine visiting a health clinic where you may be exposed to asbestos, leaking roofs and lead in the water pipes. That's the reality for remote NT residents.

title.children: Asbestos, lead, a leaky roof: Healthcare in remote NT

image.altText: A wide shot of a sign reading Tanumbirini Station with windmills in the distance.

props.synopsis: One of the Northern Territory's largest beef producers has failed in its bid to stop a gas company from trademarking the name of one of its cattle stations.

title.children: A cattle station and gas company have locked horns over the name 'Tanumbirini'

image.altText: Royal Darwin Hospital Intensive Care Unit

props.synopsis: The Acacia system was switched off at Royal Darwin Hospital's emergency department in January 2024 after it became a threat to patient safety.

title.children: Controversial patient record system to return to NT emergency department

image.altText: An Indigenous woman standing outside a construction site.

props.synopsis: Decades after Wadeye's last licensed social club was smashed to pieces amid a storm of controversy, locals will soon be able to have an after-work drink again.

title.children: Remote Aboriginal community returning to licensed liquor after 30 years

image.altText: Two men either side of an Aboriginal woman who has a soft facial expression and is wearing a blue top and blazer.

props.synopsis: Court documents reveal the Northern Territory senator rejected a $60,000 settlement offer two months before making a public appeal for help to fund her defamation defence in the Federal Court.

title.children: Court documents reveal Nampijinpa Price rejected settlement offer

image.altText: Prince Andrew looks unhappy as he is dressed in a dark suit surrounded by a crowd of people.

props.synopsis: Prince Andrew has been exiled to a kind royal house arrest but the jury is still out on whether it's enough to stem damage to the monarchy.

title.children: Something had to give with Prince Andrew but is this enough?

image.altText: A three-year-old girl with a head bandage looks on as she receives medical care at a camp in Sudan.

props.synopsis: The World Health Organization says the attack this week involved gunmen striking in several waves, abducting doctors and nurses, gunning down staff, patients and people sheltering there.

title.children: Mass killings reported in militia attack on Darfur hospital in Sudan

image.altText: An aged signpost showing figures holding hands with the words 'aged' underneath.

props.synopsis: A new fee structure for aged care takes effect today. Find out what it will mean for you.

title.children: What will aged care fee changes mean for you? Here are the details

image.altText: A red flare goes off in the crowd at a Melbourne Oasis concert.

props.synopsis: A flare let off by a crowd member at the first of three Melbourne Oasis concerts at Docklands Stadium on Friday night angers the band's co-founder Liam Gallagher, sparking an expletive-laden post.

title.children: 'You will get yours': Liam Gallagher incensed by fan's flare at Melbourne Oasis concert

image.altText: Three 18 year old girls stand next to the window in the building of a modern corridor

props.synopsis: It didn't take long for news to spread that year 12 students in nine Queensland schools had been taught the wrong topic for their final ancient history exam, leaving teenagers "angry" about the "crazy" mistake.

title.children: Students left with more questions than answers after school exam fiasco

image.altText: A red brick school building with manicured lawns and gardens.

props.synopsis: A prestigious private school in regional Victoria, accused of ignoring a toxic cycle of violence, has been banned from accepting new boarding students until it can prove it complies with safety standards.

title.children: Prestigious Victorian school's boarders ban until proven safe

image.altText: Benjamin Netanyahu

props.synopsis: Zohran Mamdani, the man many predict will become New York City's next mayor, has made plenty of promises — his one to arrest Israel's PM is causing a particular stir ahead of Tuesday's election.

title.children: 'Unenforceable pledge' to arrest Netanyahu in New York gains traction

image.altText: A brown bear gnaws at the cage it is trapped in.

props.synopsis: In the past six months, there have been four times the number of people killed by bears compared with last year, and the Japanese government wants to hire hunters to help cull the animals.

title.children: Japan looks to hire bear hunters after record number of attacks

image.altText: Conjoined newborn twins lie amongst blankets in a hospital bed.

props.synopsis: The parents of conjoined twins in PNG who were hoping to send their babies to Sydney for an operation are now trying to go to Germany instead because Australia is too expensive

title.children: Parents of conjoined twins priced out of Sydney surgery hope for German miracle

image.altText: A glass vial full of white powder sitting next to a petri dish of dark grey ore.

props.synopsis: Researchers warn Australia's pursuit of a critical minerals industry could come at a significant cost.

title.children: True cost of critical minerals becomes clearer amid chase for holy grail

image.altText: A mushroom cloud from a nuclear weapons test in a desert.

props.synopsis: The US has not conducted nuclear weapons testing for 33 years. Now Donald Trump is calling for a resumption, raising concerns about what that may involve.

title.children: Trump wants the US to resume nuclear weapons testing. This is what it could mean

image.altText: A tropical island with smaller islands in the distance.

props.synopsis: Suzanne Rees joined a hike on Queensland's Lizard Island as part of a cruise stopover. She would never make it back to the boat.

title.children: Inside the tropical island cruise that ended in tragedy

image.altText: Warren Tredrea and Mark Williams lift premiership cup

props.synopsis: The Port Adelaide Football Club continues to describe Warren Tredrea as one of its greatest-ever players — but on Friday it dismissed him from its board of directors.

title.children: Warren Tredrea was the Power's premiership captain, but has now been booted from its board

image.altText: Denmark pram

props.synopsis: This is not the first revelation about how we treat the most vulnerable in our society but such reports persistently reveal a deeper, and more distressing malaise about Australian society.

title.children: It's become cliché to turn to Scandinavia for answers but sometimes we must

image.altText: Queensland Police generic 2025-06-23 10:06:00

props.synopsis: A teenage boy has died overnight after falling from an electric dirt bike in Broadbeach.

title.children: 15yo killed after falling off electric dirt bike on the Gold Coast

image.altText: Man driving a truck

props.synopsis: Australia's road freight is set to become the nation's largest source of emissions by 2030, but a NSW trial aims to show electric heavy trucks can cut carbon.

title.children: Australia's biggest electric truck depot planned for busy freight route

image.altText: A man wearing a yellow shirt speaks to the media.

props.synopsis: Cricketer Usman Khawaja is one of the highest-profile Australian athletes who regularly wades into political issues. Now, Khawaja and other athletes have agreed to form a Players' Coalition to influence policy change on issues ranging from racism and human rights to social media abuse.

title.children: Khawaja has seen politicians 'all over cricket', now he's joining other athletes for action

image.altText: two people holding an orange t-shirt

props.synopsis: Experts warn that Australian food manufacturing is under threat as shoppers turn to cheaper imported items, but the federal government is trying to promote locally grown produce.

title.children: Government tells shoppers to buy Australian to save dwindling food industries

image.altText: A close up of Anthony Albanese smiling.

props.synopsis: The PM and his government are sitting in the often-fleeting sweet spot that comes early in the second term under our Westminster system of government.

title.children: Spectres of stagflation and soaring bills haunt Albanese's salad days

image.altText: A bald man with glasses speaks into a microphone.

props.synopsis: US President Donald Trump has justified his attacks on boats in the Caribbean as a necessary anti-drug campaign.

title.children: US strikes on alleged drug boats 'unacceptable', says UN human rights chief

image.altText: Woman stands with a sewing machine

props.synopsis: Migrant and refugee women often struggle to find employment upon arriving in Australia, even if they have experience and qualifications. A 14-week program is trying to help.

title.children: Areej has a master's degree, but she's had to 'start from scratch' in Australia

image.altText: Sarah Jessica Parker

props.synopsis: 'Spiky characters' and 'luminous writing': Here's what we thought of the prestigious literary award's 2025 shortlist, the first with Sarah Jessica Parker as judge.

title.children: Sarah Jessica Parker is a Booker Prize judge. Here's what we thought of her shortlist

image.altText: An illustration of the silhouette of two people wearing sling and bandage behind a bag of fruits and vegetables.

props.synopsis: Many young people on the Working and Holiday Visa programs come to Australia to fill labour shortages in industries like meat processing and farming, but there are concerns around their health and safety in dangerous workplaces.

title.children: Holiday workers risking injury so Australians can get meat

image.altText: High Court exterior

props.synopsis: Human rights lawyers have applied to intervene in the High Court case of a man facing deportation to Nauru, arguing the government should be barred from deporting people to places where they face death or serious harm.

title.children: Lawyers launch bid to intervene in case of man facing deportation to Nauru

image.altText: Four students sitting on chairs with game remotes as a crowd of kids stand behind them.

props.synopsis: Too much gaming time can be considered problematic. But, for these kids, it represents camaraderie, competition and the possibility of a future career.

title.children: Esports expand rural students' chance for professional career

image.altText: whispering woman

props.synopsis: They said it, we published it. Can you decipher it? See if you can work out who said what, and why.

title.children: ABC Quote Quiz: Brutal weather, a prince evicted, gen alpha slang and nature being weird … again

image.altText: A man in a dark-blue shirt stands in the middle of a winery with bottles light up on the walls.

props.synopsis: From wine in 187ml bottles to spirits in sleek aluminium cans, producers are downsizing to meet a growing demand for convenience and variety.

title.children: Alcohol industry explores smaller packaging for 'promiscuous' customers
